bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench solicits Cooke's comments on Hench's notes. He requests additional information about Camp Lazear and the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
August 26, 1940
Dr. Robert P. Cooke
State Health Department
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
On October 26, Washington and Jefferson College, Washington,
Pa. will dedicate a Lazear Memorial Building in honor of Dr. Lazear, who attended
this college before going to Hopkins. I have been asked to prepare an address on the
conquest of yellow fever. In connection therewith I have corresponded or visited
several of the survivors--Kissinger in Huntington, Indiana, Moran in Havana, General
Kean in Washington. During my visit to Havana, I learned many unpublished facts about
the yellow fever experiments, facts which are so interesting that they should be pub-
lished. I plan to do this in one of our medical historical journals. While in Havana,
I also found that the Cuban government had purchased property which they thought was the
site of Camp Lazear, and have already collected quite a sum of money to erect a memorial
to all the men connected with the yellow fever work. Curiously, I was able to show that
they had selected the wrong site, and after several days of hard work, Mr. Moran and I
discovered, or rather, re-located, the true site of Camp Lazear. I have made quite a
memorandum of my investigations, a collection of confidential notes. There are many indi-
vidual items of information which are still missing, and I am writing to you to know
whether you will be willing to let me send you this memorandum with certain photographs,
new and old, in the hope that you may be able to identify certain buildings and to give
me other data about the yellow fever experiments, based on your own experiences. Have
you, yourself, ever published your experiences thereon? If not, I shall be only too glad
to incorporate into my own story whatever data you can give me and it will be of course
much more interesting if you will permit me to quote you directly. I should appreciate
greatly whatever help you can give me. In particular do you have any old photographs
of Camp Columbia or Columbia Barracks and of Camp Lazear?

I await a reply from you with great interest and again wish to
express my appreciation for whatever help you can give me.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
